3. Investigations revealed that the accused was posted to National Service Training Institute (NSTI),
91 Jalan Bahar, Singapore, to continue his National Service (NS) duty at the said place with effect from
29 December 2002 until further notice. However he failed to report for his National Service duty at the
said place on 30 December 2004 and continued to be absent from the said place of duty without leave,
with intent to remain permanently absent without leave, until the day he was arrested by Police on 22
March 2018 .
4. Investigations further revealed that between 30 December 2004 and 21 March 2018 (Total
duration of absence: 13 years, 02 months and 21 days), the accused had neither a legitimate reason
nor any medical exemption to justify his absence. He knew of three house visits conducted by SCDF on 1
August 2006, 11 July 2007 and 20 August 2008, but did not surrender himself. The Police then arrested
the accused on 22 March 2018 after he was screened “wanted” pursuant to a police gazette; he had not
surrendered himself.
5. The accused had also been detained at the detention barracks for being absent without official
leave, on the following occasions:
a) For being absent without official leave from 16 September 2003 to 22 September 2003,
detained in the detention barracks for 12 days.
b) For being absent without official leave from 3 March 2004 to 11 April 2004, detained in the
detention barracks for 40 days.
c) For being absent without official leave from 6 July 2004 to 4 August 2004, and from 20
August 2004 to 29 November 2004, detained in the detention barracks for 40 days.
6. The accused was most recently released from the detention barracks on 29 December 2004,
whereupon he proceeded to commit the present offence. By virtue of foregoing, the accused had
committed the offence, which punishable under Section 24 of the Civil Defence Act, Chapter 42.”
Antecedents
4 The Accused was last convicted of a similar offence in Oct 2003 when he was jailed for 7 months.
5 The Accused also admitted to being detained at the detention barracks for being absent without official
leave on 3 occasions. He was last detained for 40 days for being absent without official leave from 6 July 2004
to 4 August 2004 and from 20 August 2004 to 29 November 2004.
Prosecution’s Address on Sentence
6 The Prosecution submitted for a jail term of 5 years’ imprisonment.
7 The Prosecution referred to the case of PP v Sakthikanesh s/o Chidambaram and others [2017] SGHC
178 at [87] where the High Court laid down the sentencing benchmarks or pegs to guide a sentencing judge in
determining the sentence for a NS defaulter. At [88], the Court held that within Peg 3, the starting point
sentence would be increased by one- and -a-half months for each additional year of default. Based on Peg 3,
the sentence should be about 17 months’ imprisonment. However, as the maximum penalty in the case of

Sakthikanesh s/o Chidambaram is only 3 years’ imprisonment whereas in the present case the maximum was

But on account of the Accused’s antecedents for AWOL and desertion, the Prosecution submitted for 60
months’ imprisonment or 5 years’ imprisonment.
Mitigation
8 In his oral mitigation, the Accused pleaded for leniency and highlighted that he was the sole bread
winner of the family. He also intimated his desire to turn to a new life.
Sentencing Considerations
9 The main sentencing consideration in this case must be one of deterrence. See PP v Sakthikanesh s/o
Chidambaram and others, supra. The Court in that case highlighted that the punishment for those who
defaulted on their National Service obligations had to be sufficiently severe to deter potential offenders from
evading their National Service obligations. See [48] of the case. Although the case dealt with the Enlistment
Act, I was of the view that the principles enunciated there were applicable to the present case dealing with the
Civil Defence Act as both the statutes relate to National Service .
10 The maximum punishment prescribed for an offence under s24 Civil Defence Act is imprisonment for a
term up to 10 years.
11 Besides the punishment prescribed, I also took into account for purposes of sentencing the period of the
Accused’s desertion. The Accused was a full-time Civil Defence National Serviceman enlisted on 17 Sept 2002.
He was to report to the National Service Training Institute on 30 December 2004 to continue his National
Service duty but he failed to do so for a continuous period of 13 years 2 months and 21 days. There was no
legitimate reason nor medical exemption to justify his absence.
12 The Accused is now about 35 years old. He would probably be too old to fully fulfil his full National
Service obligations. By the time he is to be released from prison, he would probably be close to 40 years old.
13 Another aggravating factor was that he was not a first time offender. He was clearly not deterred by the
fact that he had been previously jailed for 7 months. I, therefore agreed with the Prosecution that an uplift in
sentence was warranted.
14 I noted that the Accused had pleaded guilty but as was pointed by the High Court in PP v Sakthikanesh
s/o Chidambaram and others, supra, such plea of guilt would attract limited or no mitigating value. See [81]
to [82] of the case. Moreover, this was not a case where the Accused had surrendered himself. He was in fact
arrested.
15 In determining the appropriate sentence, I also used the Prosecution’s methodology by adopting a
multiplier of 3.33 to Peg 3 of the sentencing benchmarks stated in PP v Sakthikanesh s/o Chidambaram and
others, supra, at [87] and also bore in mind the relevant aggravating and mitigating factors.

16 In the case of PP v Muhammad Athir Bin Muhamed Eusope [2016] SGDC 360, the offender was also
charged under s24 of the Civil Defence Act for desertion. The offender pleaded guilty to 2 charges of desertion.

period of 7 months and 4 days). The 2nd charge stated that he had deserted for the period from 4 April 2011
to 24 July 2016 (a period of 5 years, 3 months and 21 days). The court sentenced the offender to a jail term
of 3 months and 30 months respectively. Both sentences were ordered to run consecutively. The total
